conclusion: The problem involves a circular coil with N=200 turns, area S=1 m^2, resistance r=10 Ω, connected to an external resistor R=50 Ω. The coil is placed in a uniform magnetic field perpendicular to its plane, and the magnetic induction B varies over time as shown in Figure B.
The magnetic field B starts at 0.2 T at t=0 and increases linearly to 0.4 T at t=4 s, as shown in the graph in Figure B.

premise: The magnetic flux through the coil is given by φ = B × S.
The rate of change of magnetic flux induces an electromotive force (emf) in the coil, given by Faraday's law: emf = -N × dφ/dt.
conclusion: The emf induced in the coil is proportional to the rate of change of B, which is constant over time.

premise: The total resistance in the circuit is the sum of the coil resistance r and the external resistor R: R_total = r + R.
The induced emf generates a current in the circuit, given by I = emf / R_total.
conclusion: The current in the circuit is proportional to the rate of change of magnetic flux and inversely proportional to the total resistance.

premise: The power consumed by the external resistor R is given by P = I² × R.
conclusion: The power consumed by R depends on the square of the current and the resistance R.

premise: The maximum emf occurs when the rate of change of magnetic flux is at its peak, which is constant in this case.
conclusion: The maximum emf is given by emf_max = N × ΔB/Δt × S.

premise: From the graph, ΔB/Δt = (0.4 T - 0.2 T) / (4 s - 0 s) = 0.05 T/s.
conclusion: The maximum emf is emf_max = 200 × 0.05 × 1 = 10 V.

premise: The current in the circuit is I = emf / R_total.
conclusion: The maximum current is I_max = 10 V / 60 Ω = 1/6 A.

premise: The power consumed by the resistor R is P = I² × R.
conclusion: The maximum power consumed by R is P_max = (1/6)² × 50 = 2.5 W.
